summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida today entered final judgments in favor of the trustee in possession of the Palm House Hotel, which is a "partially-constructed hotel/condominium" located in Palm Beach, Florida.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Miami, alleges that the Bankruptcy Court improperly granted the trustee's request for an expedited briefing and approval of the private sale procedures.  According to the complaint, the court granted the bidder's request to withdraw the public auction procedures and approve a private sale of the hotel.  As alleged, the Court's order was based in the bankruptcy court's sound exercise of its discretion to structure the sale procedure for a variety of reasons, including the fear of additional litigation.  In addition, the complaint alleges that Appellant, KK-PB Financial, LLC, a wholly owned and controlled entity of the Debtor, and Glenn Straub, an area developer and former owner of the Hotel, engaged in an aggressive bidding campaign in which they raised more than $7.6 million from at least 16 potential bidders, many of whom were from EB-5 investors.   The court's order also prohibits the trustee from acting as an unregistered broker or dealer in the sale of an asset, and requires the trustee to submit a business judgment in place of the court's business judgment.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's complaints, the trustee has consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins it from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders it to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty equal to the amount of any civil penalty that the court may impose on the trustee or debtor-in-possession. Â The court also issued an order requiring the trustee and debtor in possession to submit to the court an asset purchase agreement (APA) that is subject to court approval.  On April 5, 2019, the SEC filed an emergency action against Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., a Florida-based registered real estate agent, alleging that it had violated the anti-billing provisions of the federal securities laws and that it was entitled to an emergency court order prohibiting it from issuing or selling any security in connection with a pending bankruptcy proceeding.  It also ordered the trustee not to overpay for the security of the security, and to submit an application for an asset freeze in the event of an emergency.
